title: Gametogenesis
description:
The process by which specialized cells undergo meiosis to form gametes (sperm and egg cells).
Example: Sperm production in the testes.

title: Spermatogenesis
description:
The formation of sperm cells in the testes through mitosis and meiosis.
Example: A human male produces millions of sperm daily.

title: Oogenesis
description:
The formation of egg cells in the ovaries, producing one mature ovum and polar bodies.
Example: Female humans are born with a finite number of eggs.

title: Primary Oocyte
description:
A diploid cell arrested in meiosis I, which later matures into an egg upon ovulation.
Example: Present in the ovary before birth.

title: Secondary Oocyte
description:
A haploid cell resulting from meiosis I that can be fertilized to form a zygote.
Example: Released during ovulation.

title: Polar Body
description:
A small, non-functional byproduct of meiosis in females that degenerates.
Example: A byproduct of meiosis in females.

title: Fertilization
description:
The fusion of a sperm cell with an egg cell to form a diploid zygote.
Example: Occurs in the fallopian tube in humans.

title: Acrosome Reaction
description:
The release of enzymes from the sperm head to penetrate the eggâ€™s protective layers.
Example: Helps sperm enter the egg.

title: Zona Pellucida
description:
A glycoprotein layer surrounding the egg that regulates sperm entry and prevents polyspermy.
Example: Prevents multiple sperm from fertilizing the egg.

title: Polyspermy Block
description:
A series of biochemical changes that prevent multiple sperm from fertilizing the egg.
Example: Ensures only one sperm fertilizes the egg.

title: Zygote
description:
The single diploid cell formed immediately after fertilization.
Example: The earliest stage of embryonic development.

title: Cleavage
description:
A series of rapid mitotic divisions that produce smaller cells without increasing embryo size.
Example: Leads to the formation of the blastula.

title: Morula
description:
A solid ball of cells resulting from cleavage, preceding blastocyst formation.
Example: The stage before the blastocyst.

title: Blastocyst
description:
A hollow, fluid-filled structure that implants into the uterine wall to begin development.
Example: Formed about 5 days post-fertilization.

title: Inner Cell Mass
description:
A cluster of cells inside the blastocyst that will develop into the embryo.
Example: Contains pluripotent stem cells.

title: Trophoblast
description:
The outer layer of the blastocyst, which helps in implantation and placenta formation.
Example: Forms the placenta.

title: Gastrulation
description:
The formation of three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm) from the embryonic disc.
Example: Occurs after implantation.

title: Ectoderm
description:
The outer germ layer that forms the skin, nervous system, and sensory organs.
Example: Develops into the brain.

title: Mesoderm
description:
The middle germ layer that forms muscles, bones, blood vessels, and connective tissues.
Example: Gives rise to the heart and skeletal system.

title: Endoderm
description:
The inner germ layer that forms the digestive and respiratory systems.
Example: Develops into the lungs and intestines.

title: Metamorphosis
description:
A biological process where an organism undergoes significant developmental changes.
Example: Caterpillar to butterfly transformation.

title: Complete Metamorphosis
description:
A life cycle with four distinct stages: egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
Example: Butterflies undergo complete metamorphosis.

title: Incomplete Metamorphosis
description:
A life cycle with three stages: egg, nymph, and adult, lacking a pupal stage.
Example: Grasshoppers undergo incomplete metamorphosis.

title: Molting
description:
The shedding of an outer covering (exoskeleton or skin) to allow growth.
Example: Snakes shed their skin periodically.

title: Regeneration
description:
The ability of an organism to regrow lost or damaged body parts.
Example: Starfish can regenerate lost arms.

title: Blastema
description:
A cluster of undifferentiated cells that forms at the site of regeneration.
Example: Found in regenerating salamander limbs.

title: Epimorphosis
description:
A regeneration process where new cells proliferate and differentiate to replace lost parts.
Example: Limb regrowth in salamanders.

title: Morphallaxis
description:
Regeneration achieved by reorganizing existing cells rather than growing new ones.
Example: Hydra regenerating from a small fragment.

title: Dedifferentiation
description:
The reversal of specialized cells to a more primitive, undifferentiated state for regeneration.
Example: Seen in amphibian limb regeneration.

title: Transdifferentiation
description:
The transformation of one mature cell type into another without reverting to a stem-like state.
Example: Newt eye lens regeneration.

title: Capacitation
description:
A series of biochemical changes that sperm undergo to become capable of fertilizing an egg.
Example: Occurs in the female reproductive tract.

title: Cortical Reaction
description:
The release of cortical granules from the egg to prevent polyspermy.
Example: Ensures only one sperm fertilizes the egg.

title: Pronucleus
description:
The haploid nucleus of either the sperm or egg before they fuse to form the zygote.
Example: Seen in fertilized eggs before syngamy.

title: Syngamy
description:
The fusion of male and female pronuclei to form a diploid zygote.
Example: Marks the beginning of embryonic development.

title: Neurulation
description:
The process by which the neural tube forms from the ectoderm.
Example: Leads to the formation of the brain and spinal cord.

title: Somite
description:
Blocks of mesodermal tissue that give rise to vertebrae, ribs, and muscles.
Example: Develop into skeletal structures.

title: Placentation
description:
The formation and development of the placenta for nutrient and gas exchange between mother and fetus.
Example: Occurs in mammals like humans.

title: Limb Bud
description:
An early structure in vertebrate embryos that gives rise to limbs.
Example: Becomes arms and legs in mammals.

title: Neoteny
description:
The retention of juvenile traits in adult organisms.
Example: Seen in axolotls which remain aquatic throughout life.

title: Paedomorphosis
description:
A form of neoteny where an organism retains larval characteristics into adulthood.
Example: Occurs in some amphibians.

title: Ecdysis
description:
The process of shedding an exoskeleton in arthropods.
Example: Occurs in insects like butterflies and crabs.

title: Apoptosis
description:
Programmed cell death crucial for shaping developing tissues.
Example: Occurs in the removal of webbing between developing fingers.

title: Hox Genes
description:
Genes that control body plan development in animals.
Example: Determine segment identity in embryos.

title: Induction
description:
The process where one group of cells influences the development of another.
Example: Neural induction by the notochord.

title: Teratogen
description:
An external factor that disrupts normal embryonic development.
Example: Alcohol can cause fetal abnormalities.

title: Totipotency
description:
The ability of a single cell to develop into a complete organism.
Example: Seen in early embryonic cells.

title: Pluripotency
description:
The ability of a cell to differentiate into almost any cell type.
Example: Embryonic stem cells are pluripotent.

title: Multipotency
description:
The ability of a cell to differentiate into a limited range of cell types.
Example: Hematopoietic stem cells form blood cells.

title: Spermatozoon
description:
A mature motile male gamete with a flagellum for movement.
Example: A sperm cell fertilizing an egg.

title: Ovum
description:
A mature female gamete capable of being fertilized.
Example: A human egg released during ovulation.

title: Germ Plasm
description:
A specialized cytoplasm that determines germ cell fate.
Example: Present in Drosophila embryos.

title: Sertoli Cells
description:
Cells in the testes that support and nourish developing sperm.
Example: Provide structural and metabolic support.

title: Leydig Cells
description:
Testicular cells that produce testosterone.
Example: Essential for male secondary sex characteristics.

title: Chorion
description:
An extraembryonic membrane that contributes to the placenta.
Example: Aids in gas exchange in amniotes.

title: Amnion
description:
A protective fluid-filled membrane surrounding the embryo.
Example: Forms the amniotic sac in mammals.

title: Yolk Sac
description:
An early embryonic structure that provides nutrients.
Example: Essential in birds and reptiles.

title: Allantois
description:
An extraembryonic membrane involved in waste storage and gas exchange.
Example: Develops into the umbilical cord.

title: Primitive Streak
description:
A structure that marks the beginning of gastrulation.
Example: Defines the bodyâ€™s midline and symmetry.

title: Axolotl
description:
A salamander known for its extraordinary regenerative abilities.
Example: Can regrow limbs, spinal cord, and heart tissue.

title: Stem Cells
description:
Undifferentiated cells capable of self-renewal and differentiation.
Example: Embryonic stem cells can become any tissue.

title: Chondrocytes
description:
Cartilage-producing cells important in skeletal development.
Example: Essential for joint and bone formation.

title: Myogenesis
description:
The process of muscle tissue formation.
Example: Occurs during embryonic development and muscle repair.

title: Ossification
description:
The formation of bone from cartilage or mesenchymal tissue.
Example: Essential for skeletal development.

title: Neural Crest
description:
A group of cells that migrate to form diverse structures like nerves and facial cartilage.
Example: Gives rise to peripheral nerves.

title: Hensenâ€™s Node
description:
A structure in the primitive streak that organizes embryonic development.
Example: Found in chick embryos.

title: Sonic Hedgehog
description:
A signaling molecule that plays a key role in patterning the developing embryo.
Example: Essential for limb and neural development.

title: Wnt Signaling
description:
A crucial pathway in embryonic development and cell differentiation.
Example: Regulates tissue patterning.

title: Morphogen
description:
A molecule that directs cell fate depending on its concentration.
Example: Retinoic acid acts as a morphogen.

title: Epiboly
description:
The expansion and thinning of cell layers during gastrulation.
Example: Observed in zebrafish embryos.

title: Invagination
description:
The inward folding of a cell layer during early development.
Example: Leads to the formation of the primitive gut.

title: Convergent Extension
description:
A process where cells intercalate to elongate a tissue.
Example: Shapes the neural plate into a tube.

title: Notch Signaling
description:
A pathway involved in cell fate determination.
Example: Regulates segmentation in vertebrates.

title: Somitogenesis
description:
The formation of somites that give rise to vertebrae and muscles.
Example: Occurs in a sequential, rhythmic manner.

title: Folliculogenesis
description:
The development of ovarian follicles that contain maturing oocytes.
Example: Occurs in the ovaries before ovulation.

title: Zona Reaction
description:
A change in the zona pellucida that prevents additional sperm from entering the egg.
Example: Ensures monospermy in mammals.

title: Cumulus Cells
description:
Supportive cells surrounding the oocyte that aid in maturation and fertilization.
Example: Nourish and protect the egg.

title: Perivitelline Space
description:
The area between the zona pellucida and the eggâ€™s plasma membrane.
Example: Contains the first polar body after meiosis.

title: Blastodisc
description:
A small, disc-shaped cluster of cells in early embryonic development.
Example: Seen in fish and bird embryos.

title: Epiblast
description:
The upper layer of the embryonic disc that gives rise to the embryo proper.
Example: Forms all three germ layers.

title: Hypoblast
description:
The lower layer of the embryonic disc that contributes to extraembryonic tissues.
Example: Forms parts of the yolk sac.

title: Notochord
description:
A rod-like structure that serves as a primitive backbone in embryos.
Example: Induces neural tube formation.

title: Neural Tube
description:
The precursor to the brain and spinal cord.
Example: Develops from the ectoderm during neurulation.

title: Ecdysteroids
description:
Hormones that regulate molting and metamorphosis in arthropods.
Example: Control insect development.

title: Thyroxine
description:
A hormone involved in regulating amphibian metamorphosis.
Example: Triggers tadpole-to-frog transformation.

title: Chitinase
description:
An enzyme that breaks down chitin during molting.
Example: Helps insects shed their exoskeleton.

title: Heterochrony
description:
Changes in the timing of developmental events leading to evolutionary differences.
Example: Explains differences in limb growth rates.

title: Embryonic Induction
description:
The process by which one group of cells influences the development of another.
Example: Neural induction by the notochord.

title: Primary Germ Layers
description:
The three layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm) that form during gastrulation.
Example: Give rise to all tissues and organs.

title: Splanchnic Mesoderm
description:
A part of the mesoderm that forms the circulatory system and gut wall.
Example: Develops into blood vessels and heart.

title: Somatic Mesoderm
description:
A part of the mesoderm that forms the body wall and limbs.
Example: Contributes to skeletal structures.

title: Embryoid Body
description:
A 3D aggregate of pluripotent stem cells that mimics early embryonic development.
Example: Used in stem cell research.

title: Blastopore
description:
The opening of the primitive gut in early embryos.
Example: Becomes the mouth in protostomes and anus in deuterostomes.

title: Organogenesis
description:
The process by which organs and tissues form from germ layers.
Example: Occurs after gastrulation.

title: Trophoblast Differentiation
description:
The specialization of trophoblast cells to aid implantation and placental formation.
Example: Forms structures like chorionic villi.

title: Chorionic Villi
description:
Finger-like projections that extend into the uterine wall for nutrient exchange.
Example: Essential for placental function.

title: Lateral Plate Mesoderm
description:
A mesodermal layer that splits into two and gives rise to body cavities.
Example: Forms the heart and blood vessels.

title: Amniotic Fluid
description:
The fluid surrounding the embryo, providing protection and cushioning.
Example: Prevents mechanical injury to the fetus.

title: Neural Crest Cells
description:
Multipotent migratory cells that give rise to diverse structures like nerves and facial cartilage.
Example: Form parts of the peripheral nervous system.

title: Hematopoiesis
description:
The process of blood cell formation in the embryo.
Example: Occurs first in the yolk sac, then in bone marrow.

title: Endochondral Ossification
description:
Bone formation from a cartilage template.
Example: Occurs in long bones like the femur.

title: Intramembranous Ossification
description:
Direct bone formation without a cartilage template.
Example: Forms skull bones.

title: Branchial Arches
description:
Embryonic structures that develop into face, neck, and pharyngeal components.
Example: Contribute to jaw and ear formation.

title: Limb Field
description:
The embryonic region that will give rise to limbs.
Example: Becomes arms and legs in vertebrates.

title: ZPA (Zone of Polarizing Activity)
description:
A signaling center that establishes limb patterning.
Example: Regulates finger development.

title: Apical Ectodermal Ridge (AER)
description:
A thickened ectodermal structure that directs limb growth.
Example: Essential for proper limb development.

title: Hindbrain Segmentation
description:
The division of the hindbrain into distinct regions.
Example: Forms structures like the cerebellum.

title: Cranial Neural Crest
description:
Neural crest cells that migrate to form facial structures.
Example: Gives rise to craniofacial bones.

title: Cardiogenesis
description:
The process of heart formation during embryonic development.
Example: Begins as a simple tube that loops and folds.

title: Myotome
description:
A region of the somite that forms skeletal muscles.
Example: Develops into back and limb muscles.

title: Dermatome
description:
A region of the somite that gives rise to the dermis of the skin.
Example: Contributes to skin formation.

title: Sclerotome
description:
A region of the somite that forms vertebrae and ribs.
Example: Develops into spinal column structures.

title: Apoptotic Bodies
description:
Small membrane-bound vesicles formed during programmed cell death.
Example: Engulfed by neighboring cells.

title: Fibroblast Growth Factor (FGF)
description:
A signaling molecule involved in limb and neural development.
Example: Essential for organogenesis.

title: Retinoic Acid
description:
A morphogen that regulates gene expression in developing tissues.
Example: Involved in limb and brain patterning.

title: Parthenogenesis
description:
A form of asexual reproduction where an embryo develops from an unfertilized egg.
Example: Occurs in some reptiles and insects.

title: Germline Specification
description:
The process by which certain cells become destined to form gametes.
Example: Essential for reproductive lineage establishment.

title: Hatching Enzyme
description:
An enzyme secreted by embryos to break out of the egg membrane.
Example: Used by fish and amphibians.

title: Embryonic Stem Cells
description:
Pluripotent cells capable of forming all body tissues.
Example: Used in regenerative medicine research.

title: Morphogenesis
description:
The process by which cells organize into tissues and organs.
Example: Drives the formation of body structures.

title: Homeobox Genes
description:
Genes that regulate body plan development across species.
Example: Includes Hox genes controlling limb positioning.

title: Metanephros
description:
The final stage of kidney development in vertebrates.
Example: Forms the functional adult kidney.

title: Lung Bud
description:
The embryonic precursor to the lungs.
Example: Develops into bronchi and alveoli.

title: Neurogenesis
description:
The formation of new neurons in the developing brain.
Example: Essential for brain growth and function.

title: Gastrula
description:
An embryonic stage with three germ layers forming.
Example: Precedes organogenesis.

title: Spemann Organizer
description:
A signaling center that controls early embryonic patterning.
Example: Discovered in amphibian embryos.
